pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:0.5: The training rule on fine foods
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.2: At that time the monks from the group of six ate fine foods after asking for them.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.4: “How can the Sakyan ascetics eat fine foods after asking for them?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.5: Who doesn’t like nice food? Who doesn’t want tasty food?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.6: The monks heard the complaints of those people,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.7: and the monks of few desires …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.9: “How can the monks from the group of six eat fine foods after asking for them for themselves?” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.10: “Is it true, monks, that you do this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.13: Foolish men, how can you eat fine foods after asking for them for yourselves?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.14: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.15: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.16: ‘If a monk asks for any of these kinds of fine foods for himself—that is,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.17: ghee, butter, oil, honey, sugar, fish, meat, milk, and curd—
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.18: and then eats it, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.19: In this way the Master laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.1: At one time a number of monks were sick.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.2: The monks who were looking after them asked,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.3: “We hope you’re bearing up; we hope you’re getting better?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.4: “Previously we ate fine foods after asking for them, and then we were comfortable.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.5: But now that this has been prohibited by the Master, we don’t ask because we’re afraid of wrongdoing. And because of that we’re not comfortable.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.7: Soon afterwards he gave a teaching and addressed the monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.8: “Monks, I allow a sick monk to eat fine foods after asking for them for himself.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.9: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.10: ‘If a monk who is not sick asks for any of these kinds of fine foods for himself—that is,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.11: ghee, butter, oil, honey, sugar, fish, meat, milk, and curd—
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.12: and then eats it, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.3: ghee from cows, ghee from goats, ghee from buffaloes, or ghee from whatever animal whose meat is allowable.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.7: sesame oil, mustard seed oil, honey tree oil, castor oil, oil from tallow.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.13: what lives in water is what is meant.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.15: the meat of those animals whose meat is allowable.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.17: milk from cows, milk from goats, milk from buffaloes, or milk from whatever animal whose meat is allowable.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.23: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a complete Order through a procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is unchallengeable and fit to stand—
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.24: this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.25: Any of these kinds of fine foods:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.28: one who is comfortable without fine foods.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.30: one who is not comfortable without fine foods.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.31: If he is not sick, then for the act of asking for himself, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.32: When he receives it with the intention of eating it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.33: For every mouthful, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.2.1: If he is not sick, and he does not perceive himself as sick, and he eats fine foods after asking for them for himself, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.2.2: If he is not sick, but he is unsure of it, and he eats fine foods after asking for them for himself, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.2.3: If he is not sick, but he perceives himself as sick, and he eats fine foods after asking for them for himself, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.2.4: If he is sick, but he does not perceive himself as sick, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.2.5: If he is sick, but he is unsure if he is, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.2.6: If he is sick, and he perceives himself as sick, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.3: if he asked for it when he was sick, but eats it when he is no longer sick;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.4: if he eats the leftovers from one who is sick;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.6: if it is from those who have given an invitation;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.7: if it is for the benefit of someone else;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.8: if it is by means of his own property;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.10: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.11: The ninth rule, the training rule on fine foods, is finished.
